{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3360160,"name":"Erik Boyle","username":"Ekcrbe","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ekcrbe/{size}/221615_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T17:35:03.646Z","cooked":"

Shoutout to @ToddF and his recent thread for spurring me to write this up. I’ve been meaning to make this post for a couple weeks. Hopefully it can help someone else diagnose this gremlin.

This season, we experienced shorts between the negative PDH terminal and our chassis on two separate occasions. Each time, the resistance was high enough (~3.6 kOhm) that it wouldn’t technically have failed inspection, but in the interest of best practice we traced down both, and we found that they had the same root cause.

The culprit each time was a NEO 550 attached to an UltraPlanetary gearbox. The NEO 550 has four M3x0.5 mm threaded mounting holes on the front of its case. These are actually thru holes, so you can mistakenly install screws that are longer than the provided M3x8 mm from the UltraPlanetary Hardware Kit.

The first time we encountered the short, we eventually traced it back to this—we had installed M3x10 mm mounting screws instead, which obviously contacted something inside the motor. I suspect the screw was likely shorting one or more of the encoder pins to ground, because the attached SPARK MAX was also throwing an encoder fault. We initially suspected swarf had gotten inside the motor between the front plate and the outrunner, but attempting to blow out any debris with compressed air had no effect. Removing the mounting screws and electrically connecting the motor with no mechanical mounting solved both the short and the encoder fault. We replaced them with the specified M3x8 mm screws with no further issues.

However, later in the season, after everyone on the team had been made aware of this failure mode and told to be careful to avoid it, we got another short. We had not powered on the robot again at this point, so I don’t know whether we would have seen the encoder fault again. We had just replaced a NEO 550—not the same one as the first short—so I suggested the new motor was likely involved. The student who installed it swore he had used the correct screws, and indeed he had. Nevertheless, removing the mounting screws resolved the short. I took both screws to the grinder and shortened them slightly, and after reinstallation we had no short.

This one seemed more puzzling—we had done everything to spec this time—but looking into it, I think I understand. The NEO 550 drawing lists the mounting holes as being 4.75 mm deep, and the UltraPlanetary 550 Motor Plate has a thickness of 2.85 mm underneath the mounting screw slots.

This means that when installed together, the depth to the back side of the front plate of the NEO 550 is 7.6 mm. This means that the screws protrude out the back of the plate (into the interior of the motor) by 0.4 mm nominally. Not a lot, but if clearances inside the motor are very tight and the tolerance stack-up from 1.) the mounting plate thickness, 2.) the case front plate thickness, 3.) the position of the electronics inside the motor, and 4.) the length of the mounting screws is aligned against you, the problem can still occur.

Since neither instance seems to have permanently harmed the motors, I don’t have an autopsied motor to look at and verify my suspicions. I will try to remember to bring a dead one home on Monday and disassemble it if I can find one.
